However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers.
Even for civilians, however, the numbers are not all bad.
Deaths are much more likely from violent crime than political conflict—about nine to one.
The global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has spent her life fighting for human rights. She has seen many international aid projects in her country to teach and train women and girls. But too often, when the projects ended, those women and girls were left with nothing. She saw that Bangladesh needed to act for itself, so she brought together two of her passions: climbing mountains and human rights, to try to change how people see women. She first started climbing while working on aid projects in Tibet and Nepal. Bangladesh is a country by the sea and mostly flat, so most people there have never seen a mountain. Her campaign seems to be working. People in Bangladesh, and around the world, are paying attention.

Many people think developing countries are in a very bad state: trapped in extreme poverty, controlled by dictators, and with almost no hope of real progress. However, this picture is not accurate. In reality, a major transformation is underway. Over the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and escaped poverty. Moreover, each year six million fewer children die from disease, millions more girls are attending school, and millions more people have access to clean water.

Many managers try to make feedback feel nicer by putting a negative point between two positive comments. But if they do this often, employees may see the positive comments as just hiding the bad parts, so they matter less. Positive feedback should not be used only to make the negative seem less bad. It should be given by itself to support and encourage good work.

I am part of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the scary movie scene of a Terminator stepping on human skulls. Think about what is happening now. The military already uses machines like drones, automatic guns, and guard robots to kill, with very little human control. The next step could be “murderbots” that work on their own. They would follow orders, but they would still choose by themselves who to kill. I think this is completely wrong and very dangerous for people. We must be very careful about what we let machines do.

In general, more people are studying English than the other languages combined, and English is spoken in the highest number of countries.
However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers.
There seems little correlation between a language's number of native speakers and learner numbers, but there is a stronger link between learner numbers and how many countries have speakers.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent assignment.
You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong.
When you enter her office Monday morning, she starts with praise for your good work on the assignment, and you wonder if it's the expected start of 'comments sandwich'.
You know how the comments sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.

Born in the USA is a fast, foot-tapping rock album, but the words still carry strong feelings.
Behind the catchy rock tunes are stories about the sad side of the American dream.
Many songs talk about the hard times of normal, hard-working people, and the sadness and anger they feel when life brings no money or fame.
Glory Days is about people in a small town who look back at when they were young, when they felt they could do anything.
Downbound Train tells about a young man whose life is ruined after he loses his job.
It is easy to think the artist writes about real people he knew, and about the life he might have lived if he had not become a star.
This album shows the Boss’s special talent.

Lewis wants the number of protected areas in the sea to rise from 3% to 10%. He hopes this will help fix damage caused by people, like catching too many fish, pollution, and rubbish.

On his trips, he has seen this damage himself. He has swum over coral reefs that turned white because the water got warmer. He has also seen empty places in the shallow water of the Red Sea, with almost no life and plastic everywhere.

Lewis believes nature can heal if we give it space, but time is running out. If we do not start caring for our seas now, the problem may soon be too hard to fix.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award.
Born on the housing area with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car-doors with a knife.
Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these-days, appearing on popular day-shows like Police-Today and at writing-meetings throughout the United Kingdom.

Are things getting worse each day? Is progress impossible? In his book Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, more free, and happier lives. But he says there is a real problem. The values of the Enlightenment, like reason and science, are under attack. Some media and some leaders use our fear, our “us and them” thinking, and our loss of hope and trust. Then we may do harm that we cannot fix. This can damage important parts of society, like democracy and countries working together.

In old horror films, when people were in big trouble, it was hard or even impossible to call for help or call the police.
Now mobile phones make that less believable.
How do films keep the story scary?
No phone signal!
If you are the hero in a horror film, you will probably have no signal at the worst moment, when you really need to call for help.
Or your phone battery dies just as you try to call.
Or both.

In the 1950s, banana farms in Central America were losing their most valuable banana, the Gros Michel, also called Big Mike. Now the same thing is happening to the banana that replaced Big Mike, the Cavendish. The Gros Michel had a thick skin, a sweet taste, and was easy to move, so it was the main banana on farms in Central America. United Fruit was the biggest banana company in South America then. It grew bananas and sold them to other countries. The company grew huge numbers of bananas by taking shoots from the plant stem to grow new plants, instead of using seeds. It also planted them in fields where the plants were very close together.

Spider poison is present in most types and serves the purpose of stunning or killing the animals they hunt rather than attacking humans.
In fact, only 25 of the spider types we know produce poison which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly.
Australia's notorious spider from the city of Sydney, with a tube web, has not produced any fatalities since anti-poison was developed in 1981.
However, take care not to stroke spiders with hair like large pet spiders up the wrong way.
When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by shooting out a cloud of itchy hairs.
These itchy hairs then stick themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.

This horror-film cliché was especially popular in the late twentieth century. It usually begins with a group of teenagers enjoying themselves, but it concludes with everyone dead except one girl. At first, she is innocent, shy, and not particularly strong. By the end, however, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. In most cases, the last girl wins.

To find out where our ability for complex language came from, we should look at how our brains are different from those of other animals. It is not only about brain size. We also need to think about what else our brains can do, and when and why they changed over time. There are very few clear clues for this. Objects left by people who lived long ago do not show what kind of speech they could make. But the bones of early humans show changes in the mouth, throat, and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to talk.

Society, not biology, suggests that girls should prefer the arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to boys. In addition, young people see too few positive female role models working in science. Cartoons and stories often present the mad scientist, brilliant inventor, or daring astronaut as a man. There is also a harmful belief that scientists are nerdy, have weak social skills, or do lonely work that is separate from everyday life. These false media stereotypes can stop girls from identifying with scientists and make science seem like an unattractive career. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, they would gain confidence and feel a stronger sense of belonging in those subjects.

The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in department buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students.
It is written and produced entirely by students.
The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural learning and work experience.
The cost of printing newspapers is significant.
Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university.
An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as trash on campus.

At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual staff leaving rate of about 12 per cent.
Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent.
The principal objective of this report is to study why staff are involved here and, from that, offer suggestions to improve staff workplace experience and increase staff staying.

Much of what the speaker said felt true. I think there is a risk. The more connected we are, the lonelier we feel. For my generation, this is not such a big problem. We lived many years without technology. We know how to be alone, and we know it is OK. But young people under 20 are different. They are so busy texting and chatting online that they rarely spend time alone. They may not learn how to enjoy being by themselves. Also, they learn to talk by sending messages that they can edit and change. So they do not learn real, face-to-face conversation with the person in front of them.

Don't always add criticism after praise. If they always come together, the praise can feel less important and people may ignore it. Sometimes give praise by itself, and try not to add advice or corrections.
